Title: N/A

reviewText: Alright, let me explain why I love Son of the Mask: if you watch the movie JUST for the special effects, I think you will find yourself really into it, and your opinions will go up.As for the storyline and character development and all that stuff... well, there's really not a whole lot of it.  In fact, hardly none.  If there's any development going on, it's just BARELY there.  It's the type of comedy that's really far-fetched, but I honestly believe the special effects save the thing.  I've never EVER seen so many "totally out there" effects in all my life.  As you can imagine, the pacing is pretty fast too.Most of the focus is on the little baby, who really cracks me up with all the exaggerated special effects they gave him.  The same can be said for the family dog.  It's just like watching a cartoon, only it's NOT a cartoon!The effects are EXTRAORDINARY!  Not to mention NONSTOP.  You're watching one crazy effect right after another- quite fascinating to watch them and it's quite easy to get sucked in to this fantasy land of infinite possibilities.Don't worry about the characters you see on screen, or anything like that.  Just watch the special effects.
Title: N/A

reviewText: We tripped over this movie and had never watched it before because of the torrent of bad reviews.  We were pleasantly surprised at how good it was!This will never win an Oscar but it is extremely silly, has non-stop action and a kinda nice sappy theme about family unity and a father's love.  Add the recognition that even a DOG can become jealous of a new baby and the extra attention they receive, and there is room here for some family discussion/connecting about these important topics.  As a side note, I used this movie with a mask making activity with some very bored high school seniors at the end of the school year and we had a grand time.  Little bit of potty humor--but overall a keeper!

reviewText: The first Mask movie, whether considered a family film or not, was at LEAST funny for SOMEONE, well-written and fairly well-acted. This pi$$-poor, straight-to-DVD sequel is terrible. The effects are poorly-done and disturbing to the point NOBODY should show to their young children if they want them to sleep peacefully, such as the horribly-animated baby faces that make it look man-ish and angular, or the eye-less, demonic dog dragging its claws across the floor.The jokes are very poor, and sometimes just disgusting; only very young, easily-amused children would laugh at them; there's no humor (with the possible exception of Ben Stein at the beginning) adults would find remotely funny. There's no returning cast (again, except Ben Stein), so there's nothing good from the first Mask at ALL really to love. In other words, no reason to buy this. Save your money for ANYTHING else.
summary: Not for kids, not for fans of the original... for NOBODY.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Jamie Kennedy,Brendon Fraser,Tom Green, could you guys stop ruining my dream of being a cartoonist?  I may not had a creative animated thought put in paper for several years (heck, I don't even remember if I drew anything), but I do have prospects of THINKING of being a cartoonist.  Do you guys have to immerse yourself into incomprehensible, out-of-control, and disgusting situations just to prove that dreams can come true?  That sounds depressing, but (and in true critical segue fashion) not as depressing as "Son of the Mask" entirely.  This movie is as full-of-life as an ebola virus, and tickles my funny bone as well as the electric chair.Tim Avery (Kennedy) is a eccentric wannabe cartoonist who can't seem to get ahead of himself to support his loving wife, played by Traylor Howard, who wanted a child for this family.  When his dog found the iconic mask on the lake and brought it him, Tim saw the object as junk until he had no choice but to bring it for his job's costume party.  He put on the mask towards the party, and he magically became The Mask.  Just to veer off-subject from the story, I have to say Jamie Kennedy's lousy as The Mask. For some improbable reason, he was less crazy as The Mask than he was as himself; how can you outcrazy the titular character?  And once he got the party started, I had to sit through the most agonizing rendition of Frankie Valli's "Can't Take My Eyes Off You" I've ever seen.  The random zany actions and convenient choreography,that's par for the course, but the song was terribly directed and terribly sung, it was torture to watch and to listen.  Anyway, Tim in Mask form later knocked up his wife, and eventually had a baby named Alvey.  Once his wife left townto solve crimes with an obsessive compulsive detective, Tim was left alone to care for Alvey, knowing soon enough the baby has the Mask mojo.  Oh, boy.A baby crying and Jamie Kennedy trying to be funny, a combo that's utterly the most painful thing I had to experience.  But I was truly suffering once a CGI baby replaced the real baby and decided to his influence on cartoons to make his daddy go insane, and then the dog used the mask on himself to fend off the baby from doing so in elaborate schemes.  With the two CGI models duking each other out, along with a few decent animated shorts in intervals, this sequel could've been better as a cartoon.  Yea, I said the same thing about "Furry Vengeance", but that film actually made me laugh a couple of times.  "Son of the Mask" isn't funny at all, it's just painful.  The majority of the plot is just the baby and the dog imitating and ripping off much better traps from much better Looney Tunes cartoons.And then there's Loki (Alan Cummings), a villain who's recurring gag is dressing in silly clothing, being an awful CGI creature, and pulling childish pranks on parents (I know he's the God of Mischief, but this is akin to a class clown in elementary school). He has to find the baby who might lead the location of the mask, a mythological tool of his, which he has to give back to his father Odin, played by Bob Hoskins.  I hate this movie to death, but I must say Hoskins looked good as Odin, both in make-up and costume.  But Odin's nice threads isn't enough to deal with Loki, who ended up being just as much of a nuisance as the fake toddler."Son of the Mask" follows the dubious tradition of "Son of King Kong", "Son of Godzilla" and "Son of Frankenstein", and this is the worse, and also the most terrifying, Son of them all.  The cartoony antics gave me a headache, the characters are intolerant, and the movie followed an unspoken limitlessness of implausibility that frustrated me; in one specific scene when Loki became mortal for his undoings, the baby then sandwiched him with two large trash bin which, as a mortal, should've turned him into gooey remains from a"Saw"experiment rather than make him comically fall down.  This is the reason I avoid children's movies like this, because at their worse, they really make me explode in anger. Forget this hateful exercise in absurdity.

reviewText: I wasn't as appauled by this film as most people were, although not nearly as good as the original, I didn't find it to be a complete waste of time. I enjoyed the Odin/Loki story, but that part of the story gets dull fast. The movie mainly focused on the baby and dog, both who weren't funny but very annoying. With all of that said, it does a few saving graces since I did find some of it to be funny. I would recommend this film for children and extreme fans of the Mask. Casual fans and older adults will have a hard time wanting to watch this movie after one viewing

reviewText: "THE SON OF THE MASK - DVD"Sure some of the acting is weak, at times, but it's not terrible. Sure it's not as good as the original, for adults, but the kids are gonna love it. And sure the "Mask" may not be in it much, as a "human" mask that is, but the dog is the "Mask" star and he really steals the show. Just keep in mind this is a story of the son and the family dog. It's not focused on the grown-ups. I guess that's why it feels more like a kids movie?The special effects are fantastic. There are a couple of weak special effect moments, but overall they're very impressive and very intertaining. I could have done without the urinating scene and the head-spining-vomiting scene("The Exorcist"). It just seemed way too over-the-top for my liking. I absolutely cannot understand why they felt this crude humor and frightening visuals would have been funny or appropriate for kids to watch? In fact, those couple of scenes are the only negative things I really have to say about this movie. Of course, this isn't the only kids movie that pushes the bar of good taste. It really seems to be the norm anymore! However, it doesn't make it okay here.There are several, and yet again I have no idea why, curse words in it. Fortunately, for us, we have the SANYO dvd player with the built-in TVGuardian that filters out the cuss words(Wal-Mart is the only place I've seen these dvd players and they're under $50 now, too.). To me, the cuss filter is important these days because there's so many kids movies that are teaching our children to talk like sailors.I gave this movie 5 stars to help offset all the 1 stars that I feel were unfairly given. Sure there's no Jim Carrey and, yes, a few scenes would have been better with him as "The Mask" but Jamie Kennedy did okay even though as "The Mask" he just really didn't seem to be into it. Maybe that's because he knew this movie was not about the grown-ups? There's some great "Looney Toons" type fun in it that easily makes worth watching. Especially if you like wild and crazy entertainment. Just remember, the infant and the dog are the stars of the show. I think you'll really enjoy the movie much more if you keep that in mind.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I can just picture how this movie came to be:"So how else can we screw up our careers?""I know! Let's take a film that was wildly successful and make a sequel out of it!"Perfect! We'll get B-grade actors who have half the charisma and want only 10% of Carrey's original salary. We'll save millions and rake in a massive profit, never mind the fact nobody wants to see a second rate sequel with none of the original actors that made it popular in the first place! We as executives still honestly believe a movie was popular based on the name and story, not the actors who made it so in the first place!""Brilliant! Let's put a massive budget and get the cheapest actors we can find!"And really, that's what Son of the Mask can be described as. Just a simple B-grade movie that attempts to suck the life out of its original classic.Nevertheless, if the movie didn't contain the words the mask, or anything to do with the mask, it would be a nice kid's movie. For all its massive flaws and horrible acting, this really will appeal to kids because it surly did to mine. It's a good natured flick that really wants to scream out "like me!" but only those 8 and younger will truly enjoy it.Jamie Kennedy is clearly is trying to make the material work, playing the desperate dad but the script is so poor, the only thing that spews out that is worthwhile was my drink after seeing this. The character of Loki also deserves a mention, as he was the most enjoyable character and really one of the only reasons for older adults to see this film. It's too bad the character is wasted on this film; I would have really liked to have seen the character take on the true mask. Instead, we are reduced to fart jokes and toilet humor near the end.But it's a family friendly film, no naughty words, no nudity. And, hey, when you're at a kid's movie, you can't always expect Oscar winning performances. I was laughing my head off at some scenes, including one where the dog draws up a booby-trap plan to get back at the baby, and instead ends up getting caught in the trap itself. Instantly reminded me of Wild E. Coyote, getting his ACME trap to get the Roadrunner, and instead gets caught in it himself. That's the beauty of cartoons, you really don't have to think much, you don't have to ponder, just watch!While I know that this movie will never get a good rating, it doesn't deserve the '1' that everyone is giving it. It's short, at least as good as a hectic cartoon, and every bit as cheesy. I just wish New Line would have spent their money more on the plot or just done another better movie.
summary: This one is really for the kids.
Title: N/A

reviewText: So I finally decided to watch The Son Of The Mask movie because it was 2 in the morning and I had nothing better to do. Well let me tell you that if you pretend that there was never a first Mask movie this one would be ok. Sadly, There has been a first movie made and the first one kiss this ones butt. The story starts off with a tour of a museum where we see a dark character in the back of the group. The tour guide starts talking about The Mask and how the god behind creating LOKI was a terrible god who was banished. The dark figure unmasks himself and it is LOKI. Becoming angry at what he has heard he show his power and takes the mask. Unfortunately this is not the original. After that, we are shown that Jamie kennedy does not seem to want to have a baby but his wife does. His dog Otis find the mask floating in a river and he bring it home. Jamies wife pleads with him to have a baby and nothing in the world would please her more. We see that Jamie plays a character with a lot of skill in drawing but has not gotten anywhere and settles for working as a mascot. While going to a Halloween party Jamie put the mask on and WOW's the crowd. Even a high time executive. In the excitment Jamie rushes back home and sleeps with his wife with the mask on. Creating The Son Of The Mask. Loki is still trying to find the Mask and is informed by his father that a baby has been created from the mask and if he finds the baby he will find the mask. When the son is actually born we see how Jamie is actually taking to fatherhood and it's not going well. If this wasn't enough Jamies wife has to leave for a week. Making the mistake of putting the Son in front of the television to watch cartoons the baby gets all these ideas to drive Jamie insane and getting him sent to a insane assylum. Jamies dog who is jealous of the baby put the Mask on and devises ideas and puts them into action on how to get rid of the baby. Creating a funny and slap stick comedy between the baby and dog. Untimately, The story-line if you do not get it is Loki looking for the Mask. Jamie creates a baby from putting the Mask on and now the baby has the mask power. Jamie trying to coupe with becoming a father. Otis the dog trying to get rid of the baby. I will leave the ending to your imagination or you can go see the movie. I feel as though this movie was OK. Not horrible and not amazing the like the first one.
summary: If you pretend than it is ok.

reviewText: What is with filmmakers today taking CGI where CGI shouldn't be taken? I thought the Scooby Doo films had some pretty bad CGI characters but Son of the Mask takes the cake by far. The only CGI character they got away with was masked Ottis, the family dog. And that's fine. I can accept an animated green faced dog running around causing mischief and trying to blow things up in a very cartoonish manner. This worked because CGI anthropomorphism is just easier to accept and it didn't try to switch from normal Ottis to crazy masked Ottis in one or two shots. When Ottis was masked, he remained masked for a while, so really there was no comparison between the real dog and the animated dog. But with the baby, this was a totally different story because the baby didn't need the wear the mask, it was in his genes, so when he did something crazy and cartoony it went from a real shot of the baby to an instant CGI baby and this just looked horrible. The CGI baby looked like a deformed version of the real baby and when they tried to blend the real shots with the animated shots it just ended up looking really stupid and pathetic.Aside from that, the movie had some overall embarassingly stupid characters that were very badly acted and had a drunken out of control car wreck of a storyline, all about 7 or 8 years too late. Everything about this movie was just ridiculous. It completely failed at being zaney cartoony fun, something I remember from the first Mask film. Easily one of the worst films of 2005.
summary: If you have extreme ADD and are less than 10 years old you might like this
Title: N/A

reviewText: I thought this movie was good.  Not horrible, not great.  Just good.  I saw some reviews that were annoyed that the MASK wasn't in it much.  That's not surprising to me given that the title is the Son of Mask.  Honestly, I am glad that Jamie Kennedy wasn't in it more... he is not that good of an actor, frankly (neither is Alan Cumming, apparently -- I thought he was better than what came out of this film).  I really enjoyed the scenes with the baby.  My favorite scene doesn't involve too many special effects... it is the scene in which the baby crawls into Jamie's arms.  The music is very pretty... a beautiful rendition, in fact, of "Somewhere over the rainbow" sung by the Hawaiian singer IZ, I believe.As a parent, I would suggest that if you are at all considering letting your kids watch this be sure to watch it yourself first.  That way, you can decide if it is too violent or scary.  It is one of those movies that is definitely meant to be a family-flick, but certainly it is on the edge of being more for older kids who might be put off by the bad acting and toilet humor.  Still, I watched it with my family.  My wife fell asleep, I enjoyed it (I'm a male -- I love fart jokes, what can I say?), and my daughter enjoyed it.  So, two out of three.

reviewText: Most of recent films that were so wretchedly bad as to cause physical pain usually bore one of two warnings: "Directed by Paul W. S. Anderson" or "Directed by Uwe Boll". The excrement named "Son of the Mask" has neither of these warning signs, yet it manages to be worse than any of Anderboll's trash bags. If there were liquid badness, this "film" would have consisted of it: there is literally nothing even mediocre in it. Even Randy Edelman's score appears to have been written on a used handkerchief in five minutes - but can anyone blame him? I'm amazed that he did not demand that the "movie" credited Allan Smithee as the composer...
summary: So awful it feels like a Paul W. S. Anderson/Uwe Boll flick.

reviewText: I think this is a really good movie! I love it for what it is, and think it's a good new direction, instead of going back to Stanley Ipkiss. Ten years after the original, we meet Tim Avery and his sexy wife, Tonya. (Jamie kennedy does an awesome job as Tim. He's always hilarious!) Their dog, Otis finds the mask and brings it to him. At a HALLOWEEN party, Tim puts the mask on, and becomes just as zany as Stanley had. After the party, he goes home and makes sweet love to his wife with the mask on. Nine months later, little Alvey is born and has the powers of the mask. Loki, the god of mischief is looking for the mask and the baby. When Tonya leaves town, Tim has to care for Alvey, but Alvey is trying to drive him crazy. Finally, Alvey begins to like his dad. Loki finds both the mask and Alvey and holds Alvey hostage. Tim needs the mask to help stop Loki. Tonya comes back and doesn't believe whats happening. Tim and Loki use their powers to stop each other. When it comes to making Alvey pick who he wants to go with, Tim doesn't need the mask to show how much he loves him. If you love comedy, and the original, you might like SON OF THE MASK!!!!

reviewText: I sat and watched this with my grandchildren tonight and walked away with mixed feelings. Here we have a child conceived while a man wears a mask, just whose child was it? I'm not sure. As the story goes, Loki the owner of the mask comes looking for it and decides he wants the child as well, which the parents do not wish to give up.I think the movie had a lot of good effects, but it bothered me that they made out the child to be so evil and all the antics with the poor litte dog that was similiar to the cartoon Road Runner was really sad, at best.. The acting was ok, but if anyone should get a star it should be the poor little dog Otis.He got very little credit or loving even at the end.I did watch the deleted frames and I think they should have left some of them in. I would have understood more why the dog and baby were so angry. Were my grandchildren entertained?  Not really. They thought the baby was mean and felt sorry for the dog and the dad. I guess it occupied sometime but it could have been really a cute movie if just done a little different.That's my take anyway.

reviewText: Okay i admit this is movie is stupid and will never win an oscar or will the director get any credit in the movie business. And this movie will not shoot Jamie kennedy out of his B-movie profile BUT this movie is good just to get some dumb laughs in and just see a cute CGI filled movie.This movie blends in the type of humor you would get from a loony toons or tom and jerry cartoon. Jamie kennedy is very flat and not funny in this movie the only chuckles you will get from him are his face reactions to the baby causing terror.What about the plot you ask??well the story is Jamie kennedy's character has sex with his wife while he has the mask on that he found.The baby comes out and has the traits of the mask, which is mischief and cartoonish moves.And dont even compare this movie to the original since this movie doesnt even deserve to be compared to a classic.For the parents...This movie does have some crude humor and some cursing it's not really a "round up the whole family and sit them around the TV"type movie,i recommend it to kids 8 and up.Well personally i wouldnt buy this movie BUT it's worth a rental and just to pass time on a boring slow day.----The Opinionated one Has Spoken.

Title: N/A

reviewText: Since a number of reviewers trashed this movie with good reason, I will first point out the two thing that were actually good about Son of the Mask. One is Alan Cumming's performance as Loki. Alan did the best he could to work with a bad script. Sadly, not even his talented acting could save this film. The second good thing about Son of the Mask is that if you are the parent of a 13 year old or younger, your kid(s) may actually enjoy this film. Now for the much anticipated critism... Son of the Mask is actually one movie in which I have to agree with the critics on terms of being inferior to it's predecessor. The talented performance that Jim Carrey brought into the original Mask is sorely missed as Jamie Kennedy tries too hard in this sequel to come off as being humorous. At least Alan Cumming as Loki brought some dynamics to his character. As for the rest of the humor, it is much too over-the-top. If you are 13 and under, this may not bother you so much. As for me, I am a man who enjoys good comedy but the comedy in Son of the Mask doesn't even rank up to the dumb & dumber prequel. I give this dvd a second star for the good selection of bonus features. Chances are though, if you don't like this movie then you probably won't care to view the features. Oh well, at least the dvd has good picture and sound quality. Still, it is ashame that the public had to wait a decade for a sequel that doesn't rank up with it's predecessor.
summary: Was ten years worth the wait ?
Title: N/A

reviewText: Now I'm writing from Japan, where this film is now being shown as 'Mask 2.'  Probably in America, this misleading title would make disappointed and angry audiences to sue some people, those who are responsible for deceding on making the in-name-only suquel to Jim Carrey comedy sans Jim and Cameron.  At least, 'The Son of the Mask' is honest about its contents -- it's about the cartoon-writer who happens to be wearing the mask when he was in bed with his wife who suddenly becomes mother to a super-power baby.  Got it?Jamie Kennedy (so good in 'Scream' and its sequel) plays Tim Avery, an aspiring cartoon creator.  Though he is living with a beautiful wife Tanya (Traylor Howard, who happened to be in 'Me, Myself & Irene' as Jim Carrey's wife!), he is far from being a successful artist.  But one day, he gets a chance for promotion thanks to the mysterious mask that changes this painfully timid guy into the man with a green face.But as the film shows in the opening, someone else wants the magical mask (who doesn't?).  That's Loki (Alan Cumming), son of the Norse God Odin (Bob Hoskins), who orders Loki to retrieve the mask.  All right, so, this is about Tim and Loki.Wrong.  Actually, there's more to come.  Tim has got an ultra-power baby and a dog called Otis, who got somehow (don't ask how) super-power to play a trick or two (thanks to the mask ... again).  The middle section of the film is about the battle between the baby and the dog in the CGI-enhanced cartoonish fashion.  No wonder the director is Lawrence Guterman, 'Cats and Dogs.'[YOU MEAN TEX AVERY?] The job of Jamie Kennedy's character and his surname Avery are clearly reference to the legendary genius Tex Avery.  And some part of the film is shot in the way that somehow reminds us of Avery's lightening-speed storytelling style -- see the poor dog dragged by the rope attached to his tail all, yes, ALL around the house.I admit the sight gags themselves are not as bad as some previous reviews suggest.  The point is, however, how to present them.  You just cannot extend the ten minute cartoon beyond its limit.  You just cannot let someone else imitate the Jim Carrey's rubber face gags when no one else can do that.  Most importantly, you never throw these gross, tired, cliched toilet gags into the story even though you know and we know that you have nothing to do except to extend the running time.The CGIs are from ILM and Tippet Studio, which means the top brand of the industry.  And the film's CGIs would have been great in some other films.  But not here, they are wasted.  Alan Cumming in 'cute-little-girl' costume is wasted.  And my time is wasted.  Don't let that happen to you, please.
summary: Possibly the Worst Film Theatrically Released in Japan Too
Title: N/A

reviewText: Let me start of saying that technically this movie is not very good.  With that being said lets get to the meat of this review.The story is that Loki the norse god of Mischief is seeking out the mask in which he created centuries ago.  His father Odin is constantly breathing down his neck to find it and is growing impatient.  Meanwhile Jamie Kennedy is having problems of his own, his wife wants a child and his career is at a standstill.  One night while going to a Halloween party he finds the Mask and after wearing it changes his whole life.  He gets his wife pregnant while under the influence and wows his boss.  The problem is that his unborn child is given the powers of the mask.  Once the kid is born Loki shows up to take the mask and the kid.The movie itself is incredibly moronic.  It plays out like a dragged out loony toons cartoon.  However there are laughs to be had and truthfully the younger audience will appriciate this more than the older.  There were moments where I laughed because it was incredibly stupid.  However this is a kids movie, nothing more and nothing less.
summary: Not a movie to be taken seriously

reviewText: First of all, this movie is not the worst movie I have seen amongst the over 100 films from the last 10 months or so. So far The Life(Daryl Hannah) was the worst. I rented this movie deliberately to see a silly kids movie just for fun, and that's what I got from this film. It's story is absolutely silly and cheessy, but it's a non-stop special effects packed to ensure a cartoonish viewing experience. No doubt, this film should not be compared the Jim Carrey's Mask, because the story is not for adults. It actually has more special effects, and it was making me dizzy sometimes. They did so many parodies of other movie characters and celebtries throughout this film. Some of them were too silly. For instance, the baby Alvey's peeing a fountain of urine at Jamie Kennedy was too much. The action scenes were a bit violent for a kids movie. Alan Cumming was a comic force, and he did his best with the multiple character transformations.The baby had fun pulling his pranks on his daddy, and the computer assisted dance number was one of the cuter moments. If you don't take this movie as serious one, then you'll probably have some fun with it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Fun movie for the kids and the family.  Entertaining and a great addition to the Mask series of movies out on DVD.
